title: Create the Gapminder dataset
text:
# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
from gapminder import gapminder

# Rename 'lifeExp' to 'life_expectancy' and 'gdpPercap' to 'gdp_per_capita'
gapminder = gapminder.rename(columns={'lifeExp': 'life_expectancy',
                                      'pop': 'population_millions', 
                                      'gdpPercap': 'gdp_per_capita'})

# Convert population to millions
gapminder['population_millions'] = gapminder['population_millions'] / 1_000_000

# Create a new pandas DataFrame from the modified gapminder data
gapminder_df = pd.DataFrame(gapminder)

# Save the DataFrame as a CSV file
gapminder_df.to_csv('gapminder.csv', index=False)

# Print the first 3 rows of the DataFrame
print(gapminder_df.head(3))

       country continent  year  life_expectancy  population_millions  \

title: Gapminder Dataset Analysis
text:
Welcome to the website üåç
Gapminder is an independent educational non-profit that works to fight global misconceptions and promote a fact-based worldview using data. The Gapminder dataset contains historical data on economic and social indicators like life expectancy and the GDP per capita of countries over time to offer insights into global development trends.
This website provides analyses of the indicators in the dataset, exploring relationships between life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population to better understand global development patterns.
Links to Analysis Pages

Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
Life Expectancy and Population
Country Analysis





 Back to top

title: Country Analysis
text:
Over the past several decades, the Republic of Korea has experienced one of the largest social and economic transformations. From a developing nation to one of the world‚Äôs leading economies, South Korea‚Äôs rapid industrialization and investment in healthcare have significantly improved life expectancy. This analysis examines how life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population have changed in South Korea over time, highlighting key trends in its development.

# Select a country
country_name = "Korea, Rep."
country_data = gapminder[gapminder["country"] == country_name]

# Plot trends over time
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))

sns.lineplot(data=country_data, x="year", y="life_expectancy", label="Life Expectancy")
sns.lineplot(data=country_data, x="year", y=country_data["gdp_per_capita"] / 1000, label="GDP per Capita (Scaled)")
sns.lineplot(data=country_data, x="year", y=country_data["population_millions"] / 1e6, label="Population (in millions)")

plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.title(f"Trends in Republic of Korea")
plt.legend()

plt.show()











 Back to top

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text:
Economic growth is often linked to improvements in healthcare, education, and overall well-being. This analysis explores the relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy, providing insights into whether higher GDP per capita levels correspond to longer life expectancies across different countries.

# Create scatter plot
plt.figure(figsize=(8,6))
sns.scatterplot(data=gapminder, x="gdp_per_capita", y="life_expectancy")

plt.xscale("log") # Log scale
plt.xlabel("GDP per Capita")
plt.ylabel("Life Expectancy")
plt.title("Life Expectancy vs GDP per Capita")

plt.show()











 Back to top

title: Life Expectancy and Population
text:
Population size can shape various aspects of a country‚Äôs development, including the availability of health care resources. This analysis investigates how population size correlates with life expectancy, providing insights into whether larger or smaller populations experience different health outcomes.

# Create scatter plot
plt.figure(figsize=(8,6))
sns.scatterplot(data=gapminder, x="population_millions", y="life_expectancy")

plt.xscale("log") # Log scale
plt.xlabel("Population")
plt.ylabel("Life Expectancy")
plt.title("Life Expectancy vs Population")

plt.show()











 Back to top
